text: mobility in developing world cities is a
very peculiar challenge because
different from health for the education
or housing it tends to get worse as
societies become richer clearly an
unsustainable model mobility as most
other developing country problems more
than a matter of money or technology is
a matter of equality equity the great
inequality in developing countries makes
it difficult to see for example that in
terms of transport an advanced city is
not one where even the poor use cars but
rather one would even the rich use
public transport or bicycles for example
in Amsterdam more than 30 percent of the
population uses bicycles despite the
fact that the Netherlands has a higher
income per capita than the United States
there is a conflict in developing world
cities for money for government
investment if more money is invested in
highways of course there is less money
for housing for schools for hospitals
and also there is a conflict for space
there is a complex for space between
those with cars and those without them
most of us accept today that private
property and market economy is the best
way to manage most of society's
resources however there is a problem
with that that market economy needs
inequality of income in order to work
some people must make more money so much
less some companies succeed or fail then
what kind of equality can we hope for
today with market economy I will propose
two kinds which both have much to do
with City the first one is equality of
quality of life especially for children
that all children shall have beyond the
obvious health or education
access to green spaces to sports
facilities to swimming pools to music
lessons and the second kind of equality
is one which we could call democratic
equality the first article in every
constitution states that all citizens
are equal before the law that is not
just poetry is a very powerful principle
for example if that is true a boss with
80 passengers has a right to 80 times
more Road space than a car with one we
have been so used to inequality
sometimes that is before our noses and
we do not see it less than 100 years ago
women could not vote and it seemed
normal in the same way that it seems
normal today to see a boss in traffic in
fact when I became mayor applying that
Democratic principle that public good
preventable private interests that a
boss with a hundred people has a right
to a hundred times more Road space on a
car we implemented a mass transit system
based on bosses on exclusive lanes we
call the TransMilenio in order to make
bosses sexier and one thing is that is
also a very beautiful democratic symbol
because as bosses zoom by expensive cars
talking traffic it clearly is almost a
picture of democracy at work in fact is
not just a matter of equity
it doesn't take PhDs a committee of 12
year-old children would find out in 20
minutes that the most efficient way to
use scarce road space is with exclusive
lanes for bosses in fact bosses are not
sexy but they are the only possible
means to bring mass transit to all areas
of fast-growing developing cities they
also have great capacity for example
this system in Guangzhou is more
more passengers our direction than all
subway lines in China except for one
line in Beijing at a fraction of the
cost
we fought not just for space for bosses
but we fought for space for people and
that was even more difficult see these
are human habitats and we humans are
pedestrians just as fish need to swim or
birds need to fly or deer need to run we
need to walk that is a really enormous

developing country cities between

see is a picture that shows insufficient

who walk are third class citizens while
those who go in cars are first class
citizens in terms of transport
infrastructure what really makes a
difference between advance and backward
cities is not highways or Subway's but
quality sidewalks here they made a
flyover probably very useless and they
forgot to make a sidewalk this is
prevalent all over the world not even
schoolchildren are more important than
cars in my city of Bogota we fought a
very difficult battle in order to take
space from cars which had been parking
on sidewalks for decades in order to
make space for people that should
reflect dignity of human beings and to
make space for protected bikeways first
of all I have a black hair before that
and I was almost in peach in the process
it is a very difficult battle however it

worked are equally important to those

ideologically and politically if you

not be so valuable as rose
face how to distribute it between

more than 350 kilometers of protected

right justice sidewalks are unless we

protected bikeways also are a powerful

and I believe that our cities today have

tell any three-year-old child who's

for 8,000 years and children could walk

recently towards 1900 there were no cars
car have been here for really less than
a hundred years they completely changed
cities in 1900 for example nobody was

20 years later between 1920 and 1930
almost 200,000 people were killed by

cities that should show great respect
for those most vulnerable citizens such

propose to you a couple of ingredients
which I think would make cities much

are only being created hundreds of
kilometers of greenways crisscrossing
cities in all directions children would
walk out of home into safe spaces they
could go for dozens of kilometres safely
without any risk in wonderful green

would invite you to imagine the
following a city in which every other
Street would be a street only for

which are going to be built this would
not be particularly difficult when I was

this bicycle highways and the changes
the way people live move
enjoy the city in this picture you see
we're not very poor neighborhood we have

the car's still in the mud of course I
would love to pave this street for cars
well what do we do first 99% of people
in those neighborhoods don't have cars
but you see when a city is only being

because of private property of land and

respectfully passionately to those
countries which are here to urbanize
Latin America went from 40 percent urban
80% urban in 2010 I will recommend Asian
